abstract.p: The success of organizational change increasingly depends on employees taking personal responsibility for change through effective adaptation to changing conditions and proactive anticipation of new challenges. In this study, we examined how work context features influence the change-oriented behaviors of adaptivity and proactivity in the workplace. We proposed several direct and moderating effects of job context variables on adaptive and proactive behaviors. We used a multilevel design and a unique data set with 621 special education teachers embedded in 157 urban public schools to test our hypotheses. Our analyses show that adaptive and proactive behaviors are distinct aspects of job performance during organizational change and that different job features have distinct direct and moderating effects on these behaviors. Our results provide insights into how leaders of change efforts can create a work context that encourages employees to actively participate in the change process.

body.p: In the context of organizational change, some forms of work behavior are more effective and desirable (Howard, 1995). To cope with dynamic environments and enact change, organizations expect employees not only to work harder but also to engage in change-oriented behaviors, such as adapting to changing conditions and proactively anticipating new challenges (Griffin, Parker, & Mason, 2010). Scholars have argued that organizational success increasingly depends on employees taking personal responsibility for change through personal initiative and proactive behavior (Crant, 2000; Frese, Kring, Soose, & Zempel, 1996). Indeed, this active style of work behavior has been documented by organizational scholars in contemporary workplace concepts such as psychological empowerment (Spreitzer, 1995), organizational citizenship (Organ, 1988), proactivity (Crant, 2000; Grant & Ashford, 2008), personal initiative (Frese & Fay, 2001), taking charge (Morrison & Phelps, 1999), and job crafting (Berg, Wrzesniewski, & Dutton, 2010; Wrzesniewski & Dutton, 2001).

Change-oriented work behaviors are critical to organizations undergoing change initiatives, as employees often need to get involved in changing work roles and organizational practices to successfully implement organizational change efforts (Hornung & Rousseau, 2007; Morrison & Phelps, 1999). Consider, for example, evidence from successful examples of incremental organizational change documenting the critical role of personal initiative in igniting organizational change from below. Evidence suggests that proactive employees brought about organizational change, by proactively introducing modifications in product design that reflected a deeper understanding of consumer needs, or initiating a revision of a marketing approach based on new information technology (Frohman, 1997). Further evidence comes from studies of taking charge, a proactive behavior that entails voluntary and constructive efforts to create change. Employees who felt personally responsible for change and actively tried to bring about improvement in their organizations were critical to organizational adaptation and change (Morrison & Phelps, 1999). Other scholars have argued that continuous improvement in the form of active change-oriented behavior aimed at improving productivity and quality was critical for enacting organizational change (Fuller, Marler, & Hester, 2006). Finally, innovation researchers have discussed the role of employee-initiated change for long-term organizational innovation and adaptability to a changing environment (Scott & Bruce, 1994).

However, very little change research has examined the adaptive and proactive employee behaviors that promote organizational change, and how managers can develop these behaviors in employees. Only recently have researchers examined empirically change-promoting beliefs and behaviors such as readiness to change (Armenakis, Harris, & Mossholder, 1993; Cunningham et al., 2002), adaptivity (Griffin, Neal, & Parker, 2007), proactivity (Hornung & Rousseau, 2007), and change-oriented citizenship behavior (Choi, 2007), and their role in facilitating organizational change. Most change research has focused on the impact of individual differences and broader organizational factors, such as leadership and climate on employee support for change (Choi, 2007; Oreg, Vakola, & Armenakis, 2011; Wanberg & Banas, 2000). Much less change research has examined more proximal aspects of context such as factors in an employee’s tasks or relationships with others at work.

Within organizational research in general, there is increased interest in identifying the antecedent conditions that inform managerial efforts to encourage employee proactivity, taking charge, or initiating change at work (Grant & Ashford, 2008). However, most of these studies have examined individual-level differences as drivers of proactive behaviors, such as proactive personality (Bateman & Crant, 1993) and self-efficacy (Morrison & Phelps, 1999). Less research attention has turned to aspects of the work environment that may encourage such behaviors. This is a significant gap, because understanding the impact of work contexts on proactivity will provide managers with insights into creating work environments that foster employee adaptive and proactive behaviors, regardless of employees’ individual characteristics or personality traits. Recognizing this limitation, Griffin et al. (2007) and Grant and Ashford (2008) suggest that more research is needed that examines how work context influences change-oriented behaviors.

Adaptive and proactive behaviors are initiated by employees rather than prescribed or directed by others. Thus, it is difficult for managers to give direction with regard to how employees can be more adaptive and proactive. In this research, we propose that managers can shape employees’ immediate work context by providing opportunities for individuals to engage in adaptive and proactive behaviors. Clearly, there is great need to research employee adaptivity and proactivity in the context of change initiatives and the role of employees’ proximal work context in encouraging these behaviors. Given the anticipated benefits of adaptivity and proactivity in change and the need to understand the work context levers that managers have to promote them, we develop and test a model of adaptive and proactive performance and its work context antecedents.

We conducted a study of special education (“special ed”) teachers in a large U.S. public school district. The school district under investigation was engaged in the implementation of a district policy focused on scaling up a new mathematics curriculum. Given the nature of the change, implementation required changes in teacher task behavior, both in terms of actions to adapt teaching practice to new demands and proactively introduce new approaches to teaching using the new curriculum. The district policy aimed to foster teacher collaboration on curriculum planning and student assessment; however, change implementation in the form of actual instruction was done independently by each teacher in her classroom. Generally, teaching is an occupation where job performance essentially requires adaptive behavior to accommodate various learning needs in the classroom, and where proactive behavior is both possible and important in improving job performance. Special ed teaching, in particular, is characterized by rapidly changing demands (Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2010). Effective job performance for special ed teachers relies less on following standard texts, lesson plans, and examinations, and more on inventing new teaching approaches or negotiating new learning outcomes to accommodate each child individually (Crutchfield, 1997). In addition, the change context made the adaptive and proactive behaviors of teachers even more critical to the implementation of the change, since the school district relied on teachers to find the best approaches to teaching the new curriculum that fit the needs of their classrooms.

sec.title: Adaptive and Proactive Behaviors and Organizational Change
sec.p: New perspectives on work performance increasingly account for the full range of behaviors that contribute to job effectiveness during times of change. In particular, dimensions of work behavior that lie beyond what has been traditionally included in the scope of the job are increasingly important (Griffin et al., 2007). Such dimensions include organizational citizenship behavior (OCB), prosocial behavior, personal initiative (PI), and adaptive and proactive behaviors, among others (Brief & Motowidlo, 1986; Frese & Fay, 2001; Griffin et al., 2010; Podsakoff, MacKenzie, Paine, & Bachrach, 2000). Although scholars have investigated various forms of discretionary behavior, many of these behaviors are neither focused on an individual’s job nor are they change oriented. For instance, most OCB research has emphasized its promotive and affiliative aspects (i.e., interpersonal helping and compliance—behaviors that focus on improving performance by maintaining and enhancing existing work relationships and task procedures; Podsakoff et al., 2000; Van Dyne, Cummings, & McLean Parks, 1995). More recently, scholars have examined change-oriented OCB, a challenging type of OCB that integrates aspects of voice and taking charge. However, this concept may only include suggesting changes and not necessarily enacting them (Choi, 2007). In contrast, our focus is on actual behaviors aimed at adapting to new circumstances and introducing change. Another type of discretionary behavior, taking charge, can be directed beyond an individual’s job role and thus is a broader concept than adaptive and proactive behaviors (Morrison & Phelps, 1999). Finally, PI has been conceptualized as a relatively stable behavioral tendency resulting in an individual’s taking a self-starting approach to work, regardless of the situation (Frese et al., 1996). Unlike PI, adaptive and proactive behaviors vary depending on the context in which they are enacted.

Based on an integration of previous work performance theories (Borman & Motowidlo, 1993; Ilgen & Pulakos, 1999), Griffin et al. (2007) have developed a model of work performance that highlights three different types of behavior—proficiency, adaptivity, and proactivity. According to this model, in predictable environments, effectiveness can be enhanced by increasing proficiency of task execution. In times of change, work requirements cannot be clearly anticipated and prescribed, and thus adaptivity and proactivity become much more important for effectiveness. Indeed, during change, work roles emerge dynamically in response to changing demands and in anticipation of future opportunities (Katz & Kahn, 1978). Adaptive behavior describes actions aimed at responding to changing demands arising in the work environment (Pulakos, Arad, Donovan, & Plamondon, 2000). It is tailored to address problems and needs as they arise in a dynamic context and reflects one’s efforts to modify task behavior to meet the challenges inherent in novel and demanding situations. However, dynamic work contexts often require employees to not only adapt their behavior to accommodate change, but also act on the environment and initiate change themselves through proactivity (Grant & Ashford, 2008; Grant & Parker, 2009). Proactive behavior describes self-directed action to initiate change and expand the current boundaries of work roles (Crant, 2000; Parker, Williams, & Turner, 2006).

Adaptive and proactive behaviors are critical for enacting organizational change. Successful implementation of many change efforts ultimately involves altering employee in-role behavior (Hornung & Rousseau, 2007). Indeed, organizational changes that challenge work roles and goals encourage employees to act in ways that go beyond existing roles. Because change creates uncertainty and ambiguity about appropriate and effective action, its success depends on the cumulative changes that proactive employees introduce (Weick & Quinn, 1999). Adaptivity and proactivity are even more important during organizational change, because the most effective work behaviors cannot be prescribed in advance (Strauss, Griffin, & Rafferty, 2009). Indeed, adaptive and proactive actions on the part of employees who recognize and seize opportunities for creating new courses of action are critical for the success of change initiatives (see Table 1). Table 1 presents the dimensions of adaptive and proactive behaviors, their importance to change management, and their illustration in the two major categories of change (i.e., incremental/evolutionary and frame breaking/revolutionary) built on the major typologies of change found in the literature (Burke, 2008).

sec.p: Evidence from change studies suggests that active employee involvement in change initiatives is central to increasing the likelihood of sustainable change. Active involvement in change allows employees to select changes they feel they can accomplish and boosts their self-efficacy. In addition, increased participation in change efforts (i.e., through employee initiative) creates a sense of individual agency and control over the change and leads to higher readiness and support for the change (Oreg et al., 2011). Active involvement allows employees to take an active role in dealing with difficult change issues related to their jobs and increases perceptions that they can benefit from the change (Armenakis & Harris, 2009). Indeed, proactive employees respond more positively to organizational change (i.e., report higher anticipated benefits from change; Hornung & Rousseau, 2007), and are more likely than their less proactive counterparts to support and promote organizational change (Frese et al., 1996).

sec.title: Contextual Influences on Adaptive and Proactive Behaviors
sec.p: A large body of research has examined individual differences that promote positive reactions to organizational change. Evidence suggests that individual responses to organizational change are contingent on factors, such as personality traits, coping styles, motivational needs, and demographic variables (Ashford, 1988; Oreg et al., 2011; Judge, Thoresen, Pucik, & Welbourne, 1999). For example, individuals with a proactive personality (Bateman & Crant, 1993) tend to be more proactive at work (Parker & Collins, 2010), experience a higher readiness to assume responsibility for change, and persevere in making change happen (Fuller et al., 2006; Parker & Spriggs, 1999). Other dispositional variables related to change-oriented behavior are motivational characteristics, such as learning goal orientation, action orientation, and need for achievement; general self-efficacy; problem-focused coping; problem-solving style; and personality traits, such as locus of control and type-A/B personality (Frese, Fay, Hilburger, Leng, & Tag, 1997; LePine & Van Dyne, 1998; Muehlfeld, van Doorn, & van Witteloostuijn, 2011; Morrison & Phelps, 1999; Scott & Bruce, 1994).

Although this research provides useful insights for change management, it shifts the focus away from how managers can promote employee change-oriented behaviors to how they can select employees that are more likely to engage in these behaviors. Indeed, Frese et al. (1996) recommend that organizations increase job control and complexity to encourage PI, rather than solely focus on selecting dispositionally proactive employees. We think that a better understanding of the role of work context in promoting change-oriented behaviors will provide a practical avenue for managers to encourage these behaviors during organizational change and make the change efforts more successful. Work context shapes behavior because of its influence on the range of actions that are appropriate or possible within work roles (Johns, 2001). Context can shape employee adaptive and proactive actions and make organizational change more likely to happen. Indeed, context characteristics such as a supportive environment, trustworthy management, and culture have been associated with support for change in several studies (Armenakis, Bernerth, Pitts, & Walker, 2007; Coyle-Shapiro & Morrow, 2003; Cunningham et al., 2002; Jones, Jimmieson, & Griffiths, 2005). In addition, research suggests that support for change is related not only to contextual factors in the organization but also to more proximal factors in an employee’s work tasks. Indeed, discretion and control encourage employees to be more proactive during the change process and more likely to support it (Cunningham et al., 2002; Hornung & Rousseau, 2007; Fuller et al., 2006).

Among the proximal dimensions of context identified by previous research, we examine aspects of the task and relational dimensions, which have long been considered important in shaping how work roles are perceived and enacted by individuals (Katz & Kahn, 1978). They are also important prechange antecedents of organizational change (Cunningham et al., 2002; Oreg et al., 2011). Task context refers to the constraints and opportunities for adaptive and proactive behaviors that are attributable to task characteristics, such as complexity and autonomy (Johns, 2006). Relational context describes the interpersonal relationships that are embedded in and influenced by an employee’s job (Grant & Parker, 2009). Our choice of task and relational context is informed by research examining reactions to change (see Oreg et al., 2011, for a review). This research suggests that certain job characteristics relate to favorable perceptions of change and higher readiness and acceptance of change (Armenakis et al., 1993; Cunningham et al., 2002; Hornung & Rousseau, 2007). Jobs characterized by psychologically demanding tasks with high-decision latitude (so called “active jobs,” Karasek, 1998) increase motivation, stimulate development of new behaviors, and allow employees to enact change through incremental steps (Armenakis et al., 1993). Active jobs increase employees’ confidence in their ability to manage change and facilitate their participation in organizational redesign (Spreitzer, 1996; Armenakis et al., 1993). Furthermore, relational aspects of work such as supportive environments and trustworthy relationships with managers and coworkers increase intentions to support change (Coyle-Shapiro & Morrow, 2003; Cunningham et al., 2002).

To select our task context factors, we looked at literature suggesting that adaptivity and proactivity are special types of motivated behavior associated with perceptions of control and capability (Bindl & Parker, 2010). Job factors that promote these perceptions are critical during change and should be associated with higher adaptivity and proactivity. Discretion and complexity, both concerned with the degree to which employees can choose how to proceed with their work, have been positively related to proactivity (Frese, Garst, & Fay, 2007; Morrison, 2006). In support of this view, Frese et al. (2006) suggest that organizations increase job control and complexity to encourage PI. We also examine two relational context factors—social ties and interdependence. Interactions with coworkers are more pervasive than ever in contemporary work, given the increased work interdependence and the growing use of teams (Griffin et al., 2007; Kiggundu, 1981). Social ties are critical in that they provide the social support and access to information that employees need to support change and be more proactive (Fuller et al., 2006; Oreg et al., 2011). In addition, interdependence is an important antecedent of extrarole behavior and job crafting (Pearce & Gregersen, 1991; Wrzesniewski & Dutton, 2001). These four context factors are also highly relevant to our research setting and change context of special ed teachers involved in the implementation of a new mathematics curriculum. In Figure 1, we present our model depicting how work context features influence adaptive and proactive behaviors.

To structure our arguments, we use the job characteristics theory and job demands–resources theory (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007; Demerouti, Bakker, Nachreiner, & Schaufeli, 2001; Hackman & Oldham, 1980). The job characteristics theory provides insights into the motivating role of job characteristics; recent extensions that address proactivity (Grant & Parker, 2009) explain why individuals may take an active role on the job. The job demands–resources theory provides insights into the factors (i.e., job resources and demands) that facilitate an employee’s work engagement and encourage adaptivity and proactivity. In addition, given the evidence that some work characteristics may interact to predict readiness for change (i.e., decision latitude and job demand, Cunningham et al., 2002), this theory also allows us to examine the potential interaction effects of job characteristics.

sec.title: Effects of Job Resources on Adaptive and Proactive Behaviors
sec.p: Job resources (i.e., job control, social support) are job features that are functional in achieving work goals, reducing job demands and their associated costs, or facilitating personal growth and development (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007). They activate a motivational process that leads to high work engagement (Crawford, LePine, & Rich, 2010; Kahn, 1990). Job resources play an intrinsic motivational role because they foster individual growth, learning, and development (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007). According to the job characteristics theory (Hackman & Oldham, 1980), job resources such as discretion promote felt responsibility and increase motivation. They also allow employees to choose tasks that fulfill autonomy, competence, and relatedness needs and thus increase intrinsic motivation (Ryan & Deci, 2000). Job resources also play an extrinsic motivational role because they are instrumental in accomplishing work goals. Work contexts that offer many resources increase individual willingness to invest one’s effort and skills and the ability to successfully complete the task (Meijman & Mulder, 1998). Indeed, recent evidence reveals a positive relationship between job resources and job performance (Hakanen, Perhoniemi, & Toppinen-Tanner, 2008).

We expect that job resources facilitate both adaptive and proactive behaviors. Since job resources spark engagement in the task and create positive emotions, they also broaden people’s thought-action repertoires and build their enduring personal resources (Fredrickson, 2000). In turn, these positive emotions spark a desire to explore new things and should promote the development of new and creative ideas for action. Therefore, employees enjoying increased job resources will be more willing to try new things, have increased ability to adapt to changes, and become more proactive. In support of this proposition, Hakanen et al. (2008) found that job resources led to increased work engagement, which in turn sparked more PI on the job. In experimental research, positive emotions were found to trigger more flexible thinking and openness to information (Estrada, Isen, & Young, 1997) and facilitate creative problem solving (Isen, Daubman, & Nowicki, 1987). Based on the above, we expect that job resources are positively related to adaptive and proactive behaviors.

Task discretion, defined as “the degree of autonomy, or freedom of action, that an individual, team or organization has” (Johns, 2006, p. 394), is a key job resource for a large variety of jobs and occupations (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007). In a recent meta-analysis, Crawford et al. (2010) found that discretion was one of the most studied job resources across a multitude of empirical studies. Discretion promotes feelings of control and capability and should facilitate participation in change (Bindl & Parker, 2010). In addition, discretion is a core feature of teachers’ work and is considered critical for wellness in this profession (Pearson & Moomaw, 2005). Discretion is critical for special ed teachers’ health and well-being because it is associated with more opportunities to cope with stressful situations (Karasek, 1998).

We expect that task discretion is positively related to adaptive and proactive behaviors. Indeed, recent theory suggests a positive relationship between task discretion and employee adaptive and proactive work behaviors (Frese et al., 2007; Parker, 2007; Staw & Boettger, 1990; Wrzesniewski & Dutton, 2001). Discretion signals to employees that they have the ability and opportunity to take on broader roles and integrate more tasks into their work roles if they choose to do so (Morgeson, Delaney-Klinger, & Hemingway, 2005; Parker, 2007). Discretion increases ownership of problems and allows employees to recognize a wider range of skills and knowledge as important for their roles. Discretion is also likely to facilitate role breadth self-efficacy, a specific form of self-efficacy (Bandura, 1997) reflecting the influence of both personality and situational factors. Role breadth self-efficacy refers to employees’ confidence in taking on “broader and more active roles, beyond traditional prescribed technical requirements” (Parker, 1998, p. 835) and has been shown to predict proactive behavior toward one’s tasks and toward the team and the organization (Griffin et al., 2007; Parker et al., 2006; Strauss et al., 2009) as well as PI during organizational change (Hornung & Rousseau, 2007). In addition, efficacy beliefs have been identified as one of the key change beliefs underlying individuals’ motives to support change (Armenakis & Harris, 2009). In sum, we hypothesize the following:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1a: Special education teachers who experience higher levels of task discretion engage more frequently in adaptive and proactive behaviors.

sec.p: Social ties in the workplace are a key job resource in that they promote social support, resilience, security, and positive mood on the job (Karasek & Theorell, 1990; Ryan & Deci, 2000), foster work engagement (Schaufeli & Bakker, 2004), and encourage prosocial work behavior (Grant, 2007; Grant & Parker, 2009). For special ed teachers, social ties are a particularly important job resource as they allow teachers to share important task knowledge and work practices while helping them get social support from colleagues.

We expect that stronger relationships with coworkers foster employee adaptive and proactive behaviors. First, stronger social ties at work promote psychological safety, which facilitates proactive learning (Edmondson, 1999). Second, social ties are related to proactivity in implementing new ideas and solving problems (Parker et al., 2006). Third, social ties provide opportunities to learn from others through the transfer of tacit and explicit knowledge (Berman, Down, & Hill, 2002). For example, social networks have a strong effect on individuals’ creative potential and domain-relevant knowledge (Perry-Smith, 2006). Finally, social ties should facilitate more supportive and empowering work contexts, which are thought to encourage individuals to take the risks inherent in showing initiative and introducing change (Ashford, Rothbard, Piderit, & Dutton., 1998). Dutton et al. (2002) argue that individuals’ proactive behaviors are often based on contextual sense-making processes (Weick, 1979). As such, individuals assess their social context for cues about political support, image risk, and the probability of success for their actions. Stronger ties with coworkers should facilitate confidence that when one exercises discretion to engage in adaptive and proactive behaviors, such action will be well received without fear of negative consequences. In addition, social ties provide the social support that employees need to support organizational change (Oreg et al., 2011). We therefore hypothesize the following:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1b: Special education teachers who have stronger social ties at work engage more frequently in adaptive and proactive behaviors.

sec.title: Effects of Job Demands on Adaptive and Proactive Behaviors
sec.p: Job demands (i.e., workload, role ambiguity) are job features that require sustained physical or psychological effort or skills. They exhaust employees’ mental and physical resources through an energy depletion process and can lead to stress, burnout, and health problems. Although research has concluded that job demands have a positive relationship with stress and burnout, the evidence concerning the relationship between job demands and work engagement has been less conclusive (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007). A recent meta-analysis indicates that job demands have a differentiated impact on work engagement that depends on the psychological responses that different job demands tend to trigger (Crawford et al., 2010). In particular, people appraise various job demands as either challenges or hindrances. Challenge demands are typically appraised as stressful demands that are under one’s control and can promote mastery and personal growth (Cavanaugh, Boswell, Roehling, & Boudreau, 2000). Some examples include workload, time pressure, and job responsibility. Employees tend to perceive challenge demands as opportunities to learn and demonstrate competences that are rewarded in organizations. In contrast, hindrance demands are typically appraised as stressful demands that are uncontrollable and can undermine personal growth, learning, and goal attainment. Some examples include role conflict, role ambiguity, organizational politics, and bureaucracy. As such, employees tend to perceive hindrance demands as constraints or barriers that hinder their progress toward achieving goals and getting desired rewards. Although individuals may differ in how they perceive different job demands, there is evidence that individuals tend to appraise various job demands in a consistent manner because of a common understanding of the work context (Brief & George, 1995; LePine, Podsakoff, & LePine, 2005).

Since challenge and hindrance demands trigger different emotions and cognitions in individuals, they tend to induce different responses (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984; LePine et al., 2005). Because of their potential to promote personal growth and goal attainment, challenge demands tend to foster positive emotions and an active, problem-solving style of coping (i.e., increased effort, strategizing). In response to challenge demands, individuals are more confident that expending more effort and strategizing will help them successfully meet the demands, achieve goals, and see meaningful personal growth (Kahn, 1990). Indeed, research has shown that the experience of being challenged creates positive emotions and an increased sense of meaning, leading to higher work engagement and motivation (May, Gilson, & Harter, 2004). Similarly, task characteristics that promote a sense of responsibility increase worker internal motivation (Hackman & Oldham, 1980). Furthermore, an active problem-solving style of coping with challenge demands is more adaptive, in that individuals are likely to increase effort and engage in different behaviors, such as adaptive and proactive, to achieve their work goals. Therefore, we expect that challenge demands are associated with more adaptive and proactive behaviors.

Because hindrance demands are generally appraised as impeding personal growth and goal achievement, they tend to evoke negative emotions and trigger a passive or emotional style of coping (i.e., withdrawing from the situation; Crawford et al., 2010). In response to hindrance demands, individuals feel that they are unable to adequately meet these demands, are less willing to invest effort to respond, and are likely to resort to a passive style of coping (Kahn, 1990). Indeed, research has shown that the experience of hindrance demands is associated with negative emotions and psychological threats that decrease motivation and engagement (May et al., 2004). Similarly, job demands that threaten the fulfillment of competence, relatedness, and autonomy needs undermine internal motivation (Deci et al., 2001). Furthermore, a passive, emotional style of coping with hindrance demands is more maladaptive, in that individuals are likely to decrease the effort they put into the task, because they perceive that goals are beyond their control; as such, they are less likely to engage in adaptive and proactive behaviors to accomplish work goals. In sum, we expect that hindrance demands are associated with less adaptive and proactive behaviors.

sec.title: Task complexity
sec.p: Task complexity is a key feature of special ed teachers’ work and a challenge demand. Special ed teachers face increased complexity because of the diverse and changing needs of students in their classrooms, encompassing a multitude of learning, physical, and mental disabilities. This complexity is further amplified during the implementation of a new curriculum. Complex tasks have high information load, diversity, or rate of change (Campbell, 1988). They have a larger number of elements that must be considered for effective performance, are more mentally demanding, and place increased emphasis on the knowledge, skills, and abilities of the individual (Morgeson & Humphrey, 2006; Wood, 1986). In a recent meta-analysis, Crawford et al. (2010) found that complexity was one of the frequently studied challenge demands in organizational research. Furthermore, models of work design and stress (Theorell & Karasek, 1996) have suggested that demanding tasks that offer potential for mastery, learning, and personal growth (i.e., high complexity) are likely to be perceived as challenging and should facilitate proactive job performance. Accordingly, individuals performing complex tasks feel they can successfully meet task demands by working hard and by doing so they can experience a sense of personal accomplishment and receive recognition.

Complexity should enhance adaptivity and proactivity because it increases the sense of responsibility for the whole job (Hackman & Oldham, 1980) and is associated with a broader and more proactive role orientation (Parker, Wall, & Jackson, 1997). This increases adaptive and proactive behaviors by stimulating proactive thinking, self-starting approaches, and efforts to overcome barriers (Frese et al., 2007). Evidence suggests that complexity enhances PI at work via control orientation, or the belief of control over relevant and important issues at work (Frese et al., 2007). Frese et al. have consistently shown that employees in more complex jobs exercise more PI (Frese et al., 1996; Frese et al., 2007). Some have argued that very high levels of complexity are often associated with stress (Xie & Johns, 1995) and lower creativity (Elsbach & Hargadon, 2006), and thus moderate levels of complexity encourage intellectual flexibility and felt responsibility without overwhelming employees. However, research has provided mixed support for this proposition (Fay & Sonnentag, 2002; Ohly, Sonnentag, & Pluntke, 2006). Drawing on control theory, Fay and Sonnentag (2002) hypothesized and found that situational constraints, such as complexity lead individuals to think ahead about how to prevent negative outcomes in the future and encourage higher initiative.

Furthermore, individuals performing complex tasks feel less pressure to act in a prescribed manner and are more willing to engage in adaptive and proactive behaviors (Grant & Ashford, 2008). In addition, tasks that require problem solving provide employees a chance to perform in challenging and novel situations in which they can demonstrate and reinforce a sense of competence (Humphrey, Nahrgang, & Morgeson, 2007; Ryan & Deci, 2000). Finally, complex tasks should enhance individuals’ arousal at work and their interest in doing the work more effectively, which should spark new approaches and innovative ideas (Shalley, Zhou, & Oldham, 2004; West & Farr, 1990). Therefore, we hypothesize the following:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2a: Special education teachers who experience increased task complexity at work engage more frequently in adaptive and proactive behaviors.

sec.title: Task interdependence
sec.p: A large part of a special ed teacher’s job involves working interdependently, communicating and coordinating with other coworkers involved in the education of students with special needs, including social workers, school psychologists, occupational and physical therapists, school administrators, and other teachers (Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2010). Interdependence is a critical job demand for special ed teachers. Teachers need to communicate with and coordinate the work of other school specialists in their daily work but are also highly dependent on input from these workers to successfully perform their jobs.

Interdependence reflects the connectedness of jobs to one another in a work process (Morgeson & Humphrey, 2006; Thompson, 1967), such that successful completion of an individual’s work depends on the successful completion of work by others (Campion, Medsker, & Higgs, 1993; Kiggundu, 1981). Interestingly, prior research has found an inconsistent relationship between interdependence and individual job outcomes. Some research suggests a positive relationship between interdependence and subjective performance (Humphrey et al., 2007). Interdependence leads to extrarole helping via increased felt responsibility (Pearce & Gregersen, 1991). One possible explanation relates to a cognitive mechanism through which interdependence affects job outcomes; interdependence implies more opportunities to learn from others through knowledge transfer. It could also be that individuals who experience increased interdependence are likely to feel responsible for coworkers whose work depends on them and thus engage in more helping. In contrast, other research indicates that interdependence reduces motivation and work satisfaction via decreased autonomy (Thompson, 1967). Early studies on the effects of interdependence on worker outcomes conducted with coal miners support this idea (Trist & Bamforth, 1951). Similarly, interdependence involves relying on others for important resources and information and being tied to the timing and tasks of others, leading to less autonomy to act and less self-starting behavior (Wrzesniewski & Dutton, 2001).

These inconsistent findings suggest that the effects of interdependence are intriguing and clearly not well understood yet. Following Thompson (1967) and Wrzesniewski and Dutton (2001), we argue that interdependence has a negative impact on adaptive and proactive behaviors. Interdependence acts as a situational constraint on individuals and thus it is likely to be appraised by individuals as a threat to the achievement of individual goals (Crawford et al., 2010). Interdependence acts as a hindrance job demand and should impede individually initiated changes in one’s job. Furthermore, adaptive and proactive behaviors are generally directed toward changing aspects of one’s own job and not toward other colleagues, like citizenship behavior. As such, we do not expect interdependence to positively affect adaptive and proactive behaviors via felt responsibility for others. Instead, interdependence should have a negative impact on adaptive and proactive behaviors via decreased autonomy. Therefore, we hypothesize the following:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2b: Special education teachers who experience increased task interdependence engage less frequently in adaptive and proactive behaviors.

sec.title: The Moderating Role of Job Resources
sec.p: The job demands–resources theory proposes that job resources can buffer the impact of job demands on individual well-being (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007). Since job resources are functional in achieving work goals and stimulate personal growth, they can provide additional support when individuals face high job demands, by reducing the level of cognitive or emotional effort necessary to cope with these demands. This is consistent with the demands–control theory (Karasek, 1998), in that job strain is caused by a combination of high job demands and low job control. A premise of the theory is that employees who can decide themselves how to meet their job demands (i.e., high job control) do not experience job strain. This suggests that job control moderates the relationship between job demands and individual well-being outcomes. The job demands–resources theory expands this line of thought and proposes that several different job resources can play a buffering role for various job demands. In particular, the job demands and resources that are important in this moderating relationship depend on the specific job characteristics in a particular setting. Job resources can reduce the tendency of job demands to generate specific stressors, alter the individual perceptions and cognitions triggered by these stressors, moderate the individual responses that follow the appraisal process, or reduce the negative consequences of these responses (Kahn & Byosserie, 1992). In addition, the job demands–resources theory predicts that job resources particularly influence motivation and work engagement when job demands are high, further suggesting a moderating effect of job resources on the relationship between job demands and individual outcomes.

We propose that discretion and social ties (i.e., job resources) moderate the impact of complexity and interdependence (i.e., job demands) on special ed teachers’ adaptive and proactive behaviors. First, high discretion evokes the experience of job control, by making teachers feel that they can better control the job demands associated with high job complexity and task interdependence. Job discretion is also associated with more opportunities to cope with demanding situations, such as those characterized by increased complexity and interdependence with others (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007; Karasek, 1998). Second, stronger social ties are associated with increased social support from coworkers, which is functional in achieving work goals. Social ties provide instrumental help and emotional support from colleagues, which can aid teachers in coping with job demands, facilitate their performance, and protect them from the pathological consequences of stressful experiences associated with high job demands (Cohen & Wills, 1985). In addition, social ties provide additional resources, such as access to critical knowledge or physical assistance in the classroom that better enable teachers to deal with job demands and accomplish their work objectives. Thus, higher discretion and stronger social ties further assist teachers to meet challenge demands and reduce the negative effect of hindrance demands by providing additional socioemotional and cognitive support. We expect that the relationship between complexity and adaptive and proactive behaviors is stronger for higher levels of discretion and stronger social ties because of the increased availability of resources and the motivational impact of socioemotional support. Similarly, we expect that the relationship between interdependence and adaptive and proactive behaviors will be less negative for higher levels of discretion and stronger social ties because of the additional resources and emotional support provided. Therefore, we hypothesize the following:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 3a: Task discretion moderates the relationship between task complexity and adaptive and proactive behaviors, such that there is a stronger positive relationship between complexity and adaptive and proactive behaviors when task discretion is high.

Hypothesis 3b: Social ties moderate the relationship between task complexity and adaptive and proactive behaviors, such that there is a stronger relationship between complexity and adaptive and proactive behaviors when social ties are strong.

Hypothesis 3c: Task discretion moderates the relationship between task interdependence and adaptive and proactive behaviors, such that there is a less negative relationship between interdependence and adaptive and proactive behaviors when task discretion is high.

Hypothesis 3d: Social ties moderate the relationship between task interdependence and adaptive and proactive behaviors, such that there is a less negative relationship between interdependence and adaptive and proactive behaviors when social ties are strong.

sec.title: Research Setting, Sample, and Procedures
sec.p: We conducted our research in an urban public school district in the Northeastern United States as part of a larger study of district reform, social capital, and new curriculum implementation. The school district in the study was undergoing a major change initiative focused on scaling up a new mathematics curriculum district-wide, as part of a broader effort to improve mathematics teaching and learning. With regard to the various typologies of organizational change, the change investigated here was an evolutionary, incremental change, consisting of incremental steps taken to improve math instruction and enhance student learning. Implementation of the new curriculum required changes in teachers’ job behavior, with regard to actions to adapt teaching practice to new demands and proactively introduce new, more effective teaching approaches using the new curriculum. The district policy emphasized teacher collaboration on curriculum planning and student assessment, given the accumulated evidence that teachers’ professional communities play an important role in policy implementation (Coburn, 2001; Louis & Marks, 1998). However, change implementation in the form of actual instruction was done independently by each teacher in her classroom.

Teaching in public schools has been characterized by high job discretion, allowing teachers considerable opportunity to adapt and change work methods and procedures in their classroom (Warren, 1975). However, discretion levels vary across contexts. Each school shapes the context in which teachers work through the structures, controls, and operating principles it enacts to comply with district mandates, which may limit or enhance teacher discretion, interdependence, and job complexity. In addition, teachers’ professional networks within each school are thought to significantly influence teaching practice and, as a result, new curriculum implementation. Increasingly, policy makers have begun to include provisions aimed at fostering teacher professional community as part of policy and reform initiatives, such as activities that allow teachers to interact with their colleagues with regard to teaching and learning (Coburn & Russell, 2008). Prior education research suggests that teachers’ professional communities provide the trust necessary for risk taking, access to expertise to support learning, and opportunities for teachers to negotiate the meaning and implications of reform (Bryk & Schneider, 2002; Coburn, 2001).

Special ed teachers face particular challenges in their work. Because of the unique and changing needs of their students, teachers need to adapt or devise new approaches to tailor and expand their work practice. In the context of the change introduced by the school district, these behaviors are even more critical to teachers’ effectiveness since the district relied on teachers to find, improve, and refine their teaching of the new curriculum. Furthermore, adaptive behavior and being proactive can be instrumental in motivating and retaining teachers. Turnover among special ed teachers is especially costly, given the advanced certifications and education credentials required to be considered “qualified” for the job. Quit rates are quite high among all public school teachers in many urban districts and even higher among special ed teachers, whose work is seen as more demanding and “special,” and thus outside the core educational practice of the public school. In part because of their inherent “outsider” status, special ed teachers tend to report lower levels of support in their schools than do other teachers. This situation is further complicated by shortages of certified special ed teachers in many schools and districts (Kozleski, Mainzer, & Deschler, 2000).

We surveyed all special ed teachers in 204 elementary schools in the district. Surveys were distributed by teacher representatives and completed during paid after-school time. To ensure anonymity of respondents, the completed surveys were mailed directly to a third party for data entry where a code was also assigned so that individual survey responses could be matched to archival data. Teachers each received a $10 gift card for their participation in the study. Of the targeted 204 schools, 200 participated in the study, yielding a school-level response rate of 98%. We received full data on teachers and schools in 77% of the 204 schools for a final sample of 157 schools that were used in the analyses. Of the 807 special ed teachers assigned to these schools, 621 returned usable surveys, representing a response rate of 77%. We combined the teacher surveys and the archival data to develop a multilevel data set that enabled us to statistically model the variables across two levels of analysis: individual (621 special ed teachers) and organization (157 schools). Eighty-nine percent of the participants were women. The average age of participants was between 35 and 44 years. On average, participants had 5 years of teaching experience (SD = 2 years). Twenty-seven percent of teachers (n = 170) were team teaching, with the remaining 451 teachers working in stand-alone classrooms.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: We assessed adaptive and proactive behavior using context-appropriate measures (Morrison & Phelps, 1999). Our rationale for developing context-specific measures of adaptive and proactive behaviors stems from our theory. Identifying a behavior as adaptive or proactive depends in large part on the type of job being done (Frese & Fay, 2001; Parker et al., 2006). Unlike PI, which has been conceptualized as a relatively stable behavioral tendency but similar to taking charge, adaptive and proactive behaviors vary depending on the situation (Frese et al., 1996; Morrison & Phelps, 1999). Frese and Fay (2001) support this proposition with the example of developing a total quality management program. Such a program may be construed as self-starting behavior for a manager in an African context, given what is normal and expected; however, for an American manager, the same action is not considered self-starting, proactive behavior because it is simply following the lead of others. Thus, developing context-specific measures seems an appropriate strategy for our study. There are also methodological reasons for developing context-specific measures. Rather than using general statements such as “I make things happen” that reflect proactivity-centered values, context-specific measures are “more likely to result in a valid self-assessment because the socially desirable responses are less obvious” (Parker et al., 2006, p. 642).

We followed an approach similar to the one used by Parker et al. (2006) to develop our measures. We began our research with observations of special ed teachers and open-ended interviews with teachers, school administrators, and subject matter experts in the school district under study. Our aim was to better understand the nature of teachers’ work; how teachers dealt with the various issues of new curriculum implementation in their classrooms; and how teachers’ work context influenced their work. Our interviews were guided by insights from Griffin et al.’s (2007, 2010) theory of work performance emphasizing the critical role of adaptive and proactive dimensions of performance during organizational change. Based on our observations and interviews, we developed a list of more than 20 distinct behaviors that teachers considered important for job performance for the new curriculum implementation. These answers reflected job behaviors aimed at adapting to new demands and proactively initiating changes in work methods to improve the delivery of the new curriculum.

Of this set of behaviors, we identified the most “adaptive” and “proactive” in the following way. We used these behaviors as input for a focus group discussion with subject matter experts in the school district. These experts had considerable experience teaching special ed students themselves and coaching other teachers in the district and thus were aware of various teaching issues that transcended a specific school. The purpose of the focus group was to refine a sample of the adaptive and proactive behaviors identified by teachers that would be representative of teachers’ adaptive and proactive behaviors and show variance in the extent of use among teachers. The focus group narrowed the initial list of behaviors to 10 items, with 6 items for adaptive behavior and 4 items for proactive behavior. These 10 items were adopted as our survey measures. The focus group also helped us determine the most appropriate anchors to use with our adaptive and proactive behavior scales.

The survey items asked teachers to answer how often they engaged in these behaviors to make their use of the new mathematics curriculum more effective. The adaptive behavior measure (6 items) included “Teach concepts in small steps that are more manageable for some students;” “Provide shorter problems or fewer assignments for some students;” “Allow extra time for students to complete tasks;” “Use flexible grouping to meet individual student needs;” “Have different performance expectations for students in the same class;” and “Use alternate multi-sensory means to teach a concept to some students” (α = .78). The proactive behavior measure (four items) included “Use your own math games for students;” “Use songs you wrote to help recall facts;” “Use math resources you found on the internet;” and “Use math materials you purchased with your own money” (α = .71). The response format captured the frequency of using each behavior in the classroom and was informed by our focus group discussions (5-point scale; 1 = never; 5 = for all class sessions). We should note that we used self-assessments because individuals have easier access to and more readily available examples of their own behaviors and can potentially detect behavior differences to a greater extent than their supervisors or coworkers. Using self-assessments of adaptive and proactive behaviors also avoids a potential halo effect of external raters who are more likely to base assessments on overall impressions or observe behaviors designed to impress (Janssen, 2000; Parker & Collins, 2010).

sec.title: Task discretion
sec.p: Task discretion was measured with six items adapted from Jehn (1995) to fit the context of our setting. These items asked respondents to indicate the extent to which they felt they had freedom to experiment with new methods, alter their teaching approach, and have autonomy to solve teaching-related problems (5-point scale; 1 = strongly disagree; 5 = strongly agree; α = .79). We measured social ties by assessing how often teachers talked about work-related issues with other special ed teachers in the school. Since the research was part of a larger study focused on the practice of mathematics instruction, we asked teachers to report on how often in the past month they talked with other special ed teachers in their school about mathematics instruction. The frequency data, originally continuous variables, were recoded on a 1 to 5 scale (1 = low frequency, 5 = high frequency) to correct skewness. Based on information gleaned from interview and focus group discussions, we measured task complexity as the range of special needs among students in the teacher’s classroom. If teachers have students with different physical and mental disabilities, they must both differentiate and integrate their teaching to accommodate the range of disabilities and facilitate a cohesive learning experience for the class as a whole. Discussions with special ed experts revealed that the various types of disability conditions (e.g., learning disability, speech or language impairment, emotional disturbance, autism, orthopedic impairment) could not be ranked clearly according to their relative complexity, so we did not attempt to rank them in such a manner. Instead, task complexity was measured as the number of different disabilities represented among children in the teacher’s classroom. Task interdependence was measured with a three-item scale adapted from Campion et al. (1993) to fit the context of our research. The items captured the extent to which each teacher depended on other teachers in the school, and other teachers depended on her, for information, teaching materials, and so on to get their work done. The responses were anchored on a 5-point scale (1 = strongly disagree; 5 = strongly agree; α = .71, higher than the .61 and .70 reported by Campion et al., 1993; Campion, Papper, & Medsker, 1996).

sec.title: Control variables
sec.p: We controlled for several individual and organizational variables-teacher experience, coworkers’ adaptive and proactive behaviors, team teaching, school size, total number of special ed teachers in the school, school socioeconomic status (SES). In controlling for teachers’ experience on the job, we reasoned that individuals with more experience develop higher levels of tacit knowledge and a broader repertoire of work behaviors. We measured experience by asking teachers to report on the number of years they have spent in the teaching profession. To ensure that our measures of adaptive and proactive behaviors reflect the performance of individual teachers rather than the behavioral norms for the school as a whole, we controlled for coworkers’ adaptive and proactive behavior. Since coworkers are an important source of information and cues regarding appropriate work behaviors (Salancik & Pfeffer, 1978), coworkers’ behavior may influence individuals’ adaptive and proactive behaviors. We measured coworkers’ adaptive behavior by averaging individual adaptive behavior across all special ed teachers within the focal teacher’s school, except the focal teacher. We followed the same approach to assess coworkers’ proactive behavior.

Since team teaching was introduced in some schools in the district under study as an approach to integrate special ed students into regular classrooms, we included it as a control variable. Teachers in our sample worked in either a stand-alone classroom (i.e., individual teaching) or a team-based classroom (i.e., team teaching). Teachers in team-based classrooms worked in dyads, with each special ed teacher paired with a regular classroom teacher. Team teaching was measured with a dichotomous variable indicating whether the teacher worked in a team based (coded 1) or individual classroom (coded 0). Of the 621 teachers in the final sample, 451 teachers worked in individual classrooms (73% of the teachers) and 170 teachers were team teaching (27% of the teachers). We also controlled for school size since larger schools may have more bureaucratic structures and place more constraints on what teachers can do in the classrooms, thus affecting adaptive and proactive work behaviors. School size was measured as the total number of teachers in the school. Furthermore, we controlled for the number of special education teachers in the school because it may affect the frequency of individual interactions with peers. Finally, we controlled for the overall SES of the student population in each school. School SES has been shown to have profound effects on student performance as well as teachers’ approaches to instruction (Rosenholtz & Simpson, 1990). SES can influence teachers’ motivation to take initiative beyond the proficiency standards of their jobs since low-SES schools are generally viewed as more challenging work environments by teachers and are associated with lower teacher satisfaction and retention rates (Louis & Marks, 1998). Following convention in the literature, SES was measured as the percentage of the student body in a school eligible for government-subsidized lunches. A higher SES score indicates that there are more children enrolled in subsidized meal plans and denotes a school with a less affluent student population.

sec.title: Analytic Approach
sec.p: Since our data structure is hierarchical, with 621 teachers nested in 157 schools, the independence of observations assumption that underlies ordinary last squares regression cannot be assured (Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002). We used hierarchical linear modeling (HLM) to test the main and cross-level effects of individual-level variables (discretion, social ties, complexity, interdependence, and individual-level controls—experience and team teaching) and organization-level variables (school-level controls—school SES, school size, number of special ed teachers in school, and coworkers’ adaptive and proactive behaviors) on teachers’ adaptive and proactive behaviors. We specified individual teachers as the Level-1 data and schools as the Level-2 data. To estimate the magnitude of variation between schools in adaptive and proactive behaviors, we first tested a model with no predictors at either level for each dependent variable (referred to in the HLM analysis as the unconditional model). Variance decomposition between the two levels of analysis showed that for adaptive behavior, 82% of the total variance lies at the individual level and 18% at the organizational level (χ2 = 283.08, df = 156, p < .001). For proactive behavior, 91% of the total variance lies at the individual level and 9% at the organizational level (χ2 = 228.92, df = 156, p < .001). Thus, we concluded that HLM analyses are appropriate.

Because some of the measures we used were gathered from the same source, we followed suggestions in the literature to investigate whether common method approach biased our data (Podsakoff, MacKenzie, Lee, & Podsakoff, 2003; Podsakoff & Organ, 1986). First, we took measures to minimize common method bias by intermixing items of different constructs in our questionnaire, using different response formats for the dependent and independent variables, and protecting respondent anonymity. Second, we conducted Hartman’s single-factor test on the items in all our variables (discretion, interdependence, complexity, social ties, adaptive and proactive behaviors). If common method variance was a problem, then the results would show that a single general factor explained a majority of the variance. Results showed that the unrotated principal components solution extracted six components with eigenvalues greater than 1, and the first component accounted for only 20% of the variance. Thus, common method variance is not a serious problem in our survey data.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We performed a confirmatory factor analysis to assess discriminant validity among our survey-based measures—discretion, interdependence, adaptive behavior, and proactive behavior. The confirmatory factor analysis for the four-factor model (with all items in the survey-based constructs loading on their expected factors) achieved acceptable fit with a comparative fit index (CFI) of .96 and a root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) of .053. Both the CFI and the RMSEA satisfied the cutoff criteria suggested in the literature (Bentler, 1992). Next, we examined the extent to which respondents distinguished between adaptive and proactive behavior. We compared the four-factor model with a three-factor model, in which adaptive and proactive behavior items were specified as loading on the same factor. Compared with the four-factor model, the three-factor model yielded a poor fit (CFI = .83 and RMSEA = .105). Thus, the four-factor model was superior to the three-factor model (χ2 diff = 464.46, df = 3, p < .01). Finally, we compared an unconstrained model (where the correlation coefficient between adaptive and proactive behavior was freely estimated) with a constrained model (with the correlation coefficient between adaptive and proactive behavior restricted to 1.0; Bagozzi, Yi, & Phillips, 1991). The unconstrained model displayed superior fit to the data (χ2 diff = 426.15, df = 1, p < .01). Thus, adaptive and proactive behaviors are distinct constructs empirically in our sample.

sec.title: Direct Effects of Job Resources and Job Demands
sec.p: Table 2 shows the means, standard deviations (SDs), and zero-order correlations of the variables in the study. In Table 3, we show the relationship between the predictor variables and adaptive and proactive behaviors. Models 1a and 2a show the relationship between the control variables and adaptive and proactive behaviors. As expected, coworkers’ adaptive behavior has a strong positive relationship with a focal teacher’s adaptive behavior (β = .06, p < .05). We find a similar relationship between coworkers’ proactive behavior and the focal teacher’s proactive behavior (β= .19, p < .01). Furthermore, team teaching is negatively associated with adaptive behavior (β = −.29, p < .001), indicating that working in a team setting constrains a teacher’s opportunities to be more adaptive. Experience is marginally associated with adaptive (β = .01, p < .10) and proactive behavior (β = .02, p < .10), suggesting that more experienced teachers tend to adapt to various demands more frequently and be more proactive in their jobs. Teachers in schools with larger numbers of special ed teachers are marginally less adaptive in their teaching practice. Finally, school size and SES are not significantly related to adaptive or proactive behavior.

sec.p: With regard to job resources, our hypotheses suggest that teachers who report greater discretion (Hypothesis 1a) and stronger social ties (Hypothesis 1b) engage in more adaptive and proactive behaviors. Models 1b and 2b in Table 3 show that discretion is positively related to adaptive (β = .11, p < .001) and proactive behavior (β = .23, p < .001), lending strong support to Hypothesis 1a. We also found that strong social ties are positively related to both adaptive (β = .05, p < .01) and proactive behavior (β = .06, p < .01), providing strong support for Hypothesis 1b.

With regard to job demands, our hypotheses suggest that teachers who experience increased complexity engage in more adaptive and proactive behaviors (Hypothesis 2a), whereas teachers who experience increased interdependence engage in less adaptive and proactive behaviors (Hypothesis 2b). Models 1b and 2b in Table 3 show that complexity is positively related to proactive behavior (β = .06, p < .01), but is not related to adaptive behavior (β = .01, ns), lending partial support to Hypothesis 2a. We also found that interdependence is negatively related to adaptive behavior, as hypothesized (β = −.06, p < .05). Interestingly, we found that interdependence has a significant positive relationship with proactive behavior (β = .09, p < .05). Thus, Hypothesis 2b was partially supported.

Recall that the majority of the variance in adaptive (82%) and proactive (91%) behavior resides between individuals rather than between schools. Our analysis of adaptive and proactive behaviors employs HLM, limiting our ability to meaningfully describe explained variance in terms of an overall level. Instead, we computed the proportional reduction in unexplained variance at each level of analysis (Raudenbush & Bryk, 2002). As reported in Table 3, our direct effects models (Models 1b and 2b) explain 19% of the between-individual variance in adaptive behavior and 42% of the between-individual variance in proactive behavior, compared with our control models (Models 1a and 2a). Taking into account our control variables at the individual and organizational level, our direct effect model for adaptive behavior explains 28% of the between-individual variance in adaptive behavior and 23% of the between-school variance, compared with a null model (i.e., no predictors entered). For proactive behavior, our direct effect model explains 43% of the between-individual variance and 83% of the between-school variance, compared with a null model.

sec.title: Moderating Effects of Job Resources
sec.p: We hypothesized that job resources moderate the impact of job demands on adaptive and proactive behaviors (Hypotheses 3a to 3d). Models 1c and 2c in Table 3 show the results of the moderation analyses. We found that discretion significantly moderates the effect of complexity on proactive behavior (β = .04, p < .05), indicating that the positive effect of complexity on proactive behavior is even stronger for teachers experiencing higher levels of discretion. Furthermore, social ties significantly moderate the effect of interdependence on adaptive behavior (β = .04, p < .05), indicating that the impact of interdependence on adaptive behavior is less negative for teachers with stronger social ties. However, discretion does not moderate the effect of complexity on adaptive behavior. The moderating effect of social ties on the relationship between interdependence and proactive behavior was only marginally significant (β = .03, p < .10). Thus, we found partial support for Hypotheses 3a and 3d. Furthermore, the impact of complexity on adaptive and proactive behaviors was not moderated by social ties, indicating no support for Hypothesis 3b. Finally, we did not find any moderating effects of discretion on the relationship between interdependence and adaptive and proactive behaviors. Thus, Hypothesis 3c was not supported. Each of our interaction models (Model 1c and 2c) explains an additional 1% between-individual variance in adaptive and proactive behavior, respectively, compared with the main effect models (Models 1b and 2b).

To examine the nature of the significant interactions found, we first plotted simple regression lines representing the relationship between complexity and proactive behavior separately for low (1 SD below the mean) and high (1 SD above the mean) levels of discretion (Figure 2A). We analyzed the interactions following the approach suggested by Preacher, Curran, and Bauer (2006). As shown in Figure 2A, social ties had a significant boosting effect on the relationship between interdependence and adaptive behavior. In terms of the magnitude of this effect, a 1 SD increase in interdependence is associated with a 0.02% decrease in adaptive behavior for teachers with weak social ties but a 10.5% increase in adaptive behavior for teachers with strong social ties. We also plotted simple regression lines representing the relationship between interdependence and adaptive behavior for weak (1 SD below the mean) and strong (1 SD above the mean) social ties (Figure 2B). As shown, discretion had a significant boosting effect on the relationship between complexity and proactive behavior. In terms of the magnitude of this effect, a 1 SD increase in complexity is associated with a 25.9% increase in proactive behavior for teachers with low discretion, and a much larger 37.1% increase in proactive behavior for teachers with high discretion.
