sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In times of organizational change, employees must adapt to new demands and proactively implement new ideas to make the change efforts successful. Although scholars have recognized that organizational change success is ultimately contingent on changing individual behavior (Robertson, Roberts, & Porras, 1993), little research has considered how to promote employee adaptivity and proactivity, behaviors with particular relevance to organizational change. Since adaptivity and proactivity are emergent and cannot be prescribed in advance, change leaders face a challenge in that they cannot simply direct employees to be more adaptive and proactive. Instead, change leaders can encourage adaptivity and proactivity by shaping a work environment that stimulates these behaviors. Our findings suggest that employees’ proximal work context, in both its task and relational aspects, can motivate more adaptivity and proactivity. These findings converge with those of Fuller et al. (2006) and Hornung and Rousseau (2007), who found that employees enjoying more autonomy and increased access to information and resources are better positioned to be more proactive and support organizational change.

Our results show that adaptivity and proactivity are distinct types of change-oriented behavior that relate to features of the job. With regard to broader patterns that emerged from our data, discretion and social ties had a positive impact on adaptive and proactive behaviors, consistent with our hypotheses. Furthermore, and consistent with our predictions, complexity was associated with more teacher proactive behavior. However, teachers experiencing increased complexity did not engage in more adaptive behavior. This comports with earlier arguments in the organizational learning literature (March, 1991) suggesting that complex job demands are associated with the generation of new routines and work practices (i.e., proactive exploration), but not with the selection among existing routines and practices (i.e., adaptive exploitation). In addition, our findings highlight the importance of discretion and social ties in encouraging the behaviors that are so critical for implementing incremental change (Table 1). In such contexts, organizations rely on employees’ continuous efforts to adapt to new circumstances, cope with changes in tasks, proactively solve problems, and initiate improvements.

Furthermore, we found that interdependence had a negative impact on adaptive behavior, as hypothesized, but a positive impact on proactive behavior. The negative impact on adaptive behavior is consistent with our hypothesis that interdependence was experienced by teachers as a hindrance demand. The finding that interdependence leads to more proactivity is intriguing, given earlier arguments in organizational literature suggesting that interdependence is a constraint on change-oriented behaviors such as job crafting (Wrzesniewski & Dutton, 2001). It may be that more interdependent workers had more opportunities to draw on expanded resources and ideas from others and thus become more proactive. The benefits of increased interdependence may be greater when rewards and feedback, like goals, are provided at the group level, congruent with the interdependent nature of work (Wageman, 1995). Since job effectiveness for special ed teachers is dependent on information and resources from various others, such as psychologists, social workers, school administrators, occupational and physical therapists, and other teachers, this outcome interdependence may have provided teachers with increased motivation to draw on diverse knowledge and proactively initiate improvements in their practice. This is consistent with research suggesting that interdependence has more benefits in diverse groups because it encourages cooperation and sharing of information from novel perspectives (Jehn, Northcraft, & Neal, 1999). Finally, it could also be that individuals experience interdependence as a hindrance and a challenge simultaneously (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984). However, more research is needed to understand how interdependence influences proactivity.

With regard to moderating effects, we found that complexity was associated with more proactive behavior for teachers experiencing increased discretion compared with those who reported lower discretion. Similarly, interdependence was associated with more adaptive behavior for teachers with strong social ties with peers compared with those whose social ties were weak. These findings are consistent with the buffering hypothesis regarding the moderating impact of job resources (Bakker & Demerouti, 2007). However, we were surprised by the lack of support for the interaction between discretion and interdependence and between social ties and complexity. Recently, scholars have highlighted some costs of individual discretion under conditions of high interdependence. When interdependence is high, individual autonomy can undermine group performance by reducing group cohesiveness (Langfred, 2005). When interdependence is low, individual autonomy facilitates the motivation and performance benefits predicted by the job characteristics theory (Fried & Ferris, 1987). This suggests an interaction effect in the opposite direction than our prediction. However, in our case, these interactions were not significant, suggesting that more research is needed to better understand these effects. Finally, since interaction effects are often difficult to detect in field studies (McClelland & Judd, 1993), we may have not been able to detect a significant moderation effect with our sample. Clearly, the interactions in our study suggest potentially important relationships that may warrant further study.

The effects of some of the control variables considered in our analysis are also noteworthy. For instance, teacher experience was positively associated with both adaptive and proactive behavior. This suggests that more experienced teachers were likely to develop more tacit knowledge and a broader repertoire of work behaviors to use when facing changing work demands. Furthermore, team teaching was negatively related to adaptive behavior, indicating that working collaboratively in a team reduces one’s ability to adapt to the challenges inherent in changing situations. This finding is consistent with those of Berg et al. (2010), who argued that one’s relative invisibility in the social system of the organization endows people with a greater sense of freedom to be adaptive. In our study, special ed teachers working alone in the classroom were less visible to other teachers than their colleagues working in collaborative classrooms. In addition, our results suggest that peer norms have a significant impact on teacher behavior. In particular, teachers embedded in schools where their coworkers engaged in more frequent adaptive and proactive behaviors were more likely to be themselves more adaptive and proactive, respectively. This is consistent with earlier research suggesting that teachers’ professional communities play an important role in change policy implementation (Louis & Marks, 1998). Finally, we should note that we did not have access to school overall performance data. Controlling for school performance in our analysis would have allowed us to ensure adaptive and proactive behaviors do not reflect a boost in self-efficacy due to school-level factors. It could be argued that teachers in high-performing schools (i.e., higher student scores) may be more willing to take risks and be more proactive in dealing with changing demands because of their increased self-efficacy.

Our research has implications for organizational change theory and practice. The change context investigated in this research, the implementation of a new mathematics curriculum in public schools, highlights an important aspect of planned organizational change. Change that alters performance goals and work roles encourages employees to adapt to changing demands, as well as anticipate, plan ahead, and act in advance to create change. Our research underscores the importance of individual behavioral change in models of planned organizational change. Indeed, without individual behavioral change, successful organizational change is not possible. In addition, our findings suggest that organizations undergoing change may facilitate these behaviors by allowing increased discretion and encouraging social interaction with coworkers. Since organizations often cannot reduce the demands placed on employees (i.e., decrease complexity or interdependence with others), our research suggests an avenue to increase adaptivity and proactivity in challenging situations—that is, providing more resources that increase flexibility, access to knowledge, and social support from others. Of course, the public school context in our research allows for increased levels of discretion and social interaction with coworkers, given the nature of the teaching occupation. In other organizational contexts, this may be done through job rotation, developing broader skills, sharing information about the larger context in which one’s job is performed, enhanced opportunities for interactions with coworkers, and increased discretion in decision making related to one’s job.

The interaction of social ties and interdependence suggests some practical implications for managing organizational change. In order to mitigate the limited opportunities that interdependent work provides for individual adaptation to change, change leaders can encourage the development of stronger professional communities at work. Our findings highlight the critical role of employees’ professional communities at work in providing interdependent workers the trust necessary for taking risks to be proactive during change; in addition, professional communities at work offer employees the opportunity to negotiate the meaning of change and its implications for each individual involved in organizational change.

Our results further suggest that adaptivity and proactivity can be useful in managing efforts at two stages of the change process. First, active employee involvement in the change process (i.e., through increased opportunities to have a say in how employees deal with the change) is an important influence strategy that change leaders can use to create readiness for change (Armenakis & Harris, 2009). Active participation through adaptivity and proactivity contributes to increased feelings of efficacy that underlie employees’ readiness for change and their motives to support the change. Second, adaptivity and proactivity are important aspects in the change adoption and institutionalization phase (see Table 1). They allow individuals to adapt effectively to new circumstances created by the change and initiate changes in their work that are consistent with the larger change effort. In addition, employees who are adaptive and proactive during change will be more committed to the change process, will internalize the change effort, and contribute to its institutionalization.

From a theory perspective, our study complements previous research on change antecedents, such as innovative climate, access to strategy information, and supportive and visionary leadership (Choi, 2007; Griffin et al., 2010; Wanberg & Banas, 2000). Our research highlights the importance of more proximal factors in an individual’s task and relational context that encourage adaptive and proactive behaviors during change. Of course, contextual factors are unlikely to be sufficient on their own in increasing adaptivity and proactivity during change. When enabling contextual factors are present, individuals will be more adaptive and proactive if critical beliefs, such as self-efficacy and felt responsibility for change are activated (Choi, 2007; Fuller et al., 2006; Hornung & Rousseau, 2007). The importance of these beliefs for implementing change gives rise to the question as to how one can build greater self-efficacy and felt responsibility for change. Evidence suggests that role breadth self-efficacy can be enhanced over time through enriched work design (Hornung & Rousseau, 2007; Parker, 1998). Of course, we did not have data to test these mediating effects, but future research should examine in more depth the intervening mechanisms through which the task and relational facets of work context encourage adaptivity and proactivity during change.

We should also note that individuals’ adaptive and proactive behaviors may also reflect attempts to achieve a better fit between the job and their own skills, motivations, and interests at work (Wrzesniewski & Dutton, 2001). In particular, organizational change affects the fit between employees and various aspects of their work environment (person–environment fit; O’Reilly, Chatman, & Caldwell, 1991). Thus, change can trigger realignment of the relationship between individuals and their work environment through individual efforts to adapt to the new work environment and proactively plan and initiate changes. When change alters individual jobs, employees will likely assess the fit and attempt realignment between the new demands and their abilities (person–job fit). Given that organizational change relates to person–environment realignment, and given the important outcomes associated with increased or decreased fit, the direct implication is that organizations undergoing change need to pay attention to fit issues as they can affect employee reactions to and support for change, ultimately affecting the success of change initiatives (Caldwell, Herold, & Fedor, 2004). Indeed, person–environment fit perceptions are important to both employees (i.e., change participants) and managers (i.e., change agents), because they relate to critical outcomes, such as job satisfaction, organizational commitment, and intentions to quit. Since employees tend to focus more on the impact of change on their immediate work environment than on the meaning of the larger organizational-level change, change agents’ assessment of change needs to capture the more proximal impact of change on the daily work routines and practices through change participants’ adaptive and proactive behaviors (Burke & Litwin, 1992; Lau & Woodman, 1995).

Another aspect that is worth discussing is the organizational implications of adaptivity and proactivity. We have argued, consistent with previous research (Frese & Fay, 2001; Griffin et al., 2010; Morrison & Phelps, 1999), that adaptivity and proactivity are functional for the organization and facilitate change implementation. Evidence also shows that proactivity leads to increased support for the change (Hornung & Rousseau, 2007) and thus should positively influence its success. However, some scholars have recently argued that proactivity may have negative consequences under certain circumstances (Belschak, den Hartog, & Fay, 2010). For example, high proactivity should lead to positive consequences when employees have high knowledge and skills (Frese et al., 2007); however, when coupled with low skills, it may lead to low performance (Chan, 2006) and low ability to be adaptive and proactive during change. However, we did not have the opportunity to measure organizational performance at the end of the change process. This would have allowed us to establish a direct link between teachers’ adaptive and proactive behaviors and change outcomes. We encourage further research in this direction, particularly longitudinal research that unpacks the underlying dynamics of the relationships between work context, adaptive and proactive behaviors, and change outcomes.

We extend organizational research by examining the impact of job resources and demands on active job performance facets that are critical for the success of organizational change. Recently, the job design literature has begun to depict a more fluid image of work roles, a more agentic view of job holders as crafters of their work (Wrzesniewski & Dutton, 2001), and a more relational view of job design (Grant & Parker, 2009). We focus on these emergent work behaviors, distinguish theoretically and empirically between two forms of such behavior—adaptive and proactive—and incorporate relational elements of context in our model of adaptive and proactive performance. In addition, we provide evidence that change-oriented behaviors are socially embedded processes. We found that the relational context of work plays a key role in encouraging both adaptive and proactive behaviors. This enabling role suggests that social ties may shape the opportunities available to be adaptive and proactive at work and the perceived ability to act on these opportunities during change. Within the context of reform initiatives in public schools, our findings show that school administrators can encourage adaptive and proactive behaviors during change through enabling contexts that allow teachers to use the discretion and complexity in their work and by encouraging contexts where teachers can form stronger social ties.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations of the Research
sec.p: Our study is not without limitations. Many of our measures are employee self-reports, including our measures of adaptive and proactive behaviors, and thus the relationships among the variables could be inflated by common method bias. However, as discussed earlier, there are good reasons why we used self-assessments of adaptive and proactive behaviors. Individuals have easier access and more readily available examples of their own behaviors and can potentially detect differences among their behaviors to a greater extent than supervisors or coworkers. Using self-assessments of adaptive and proactive behaviors is also likely to produce more accurate results by avoiding the potential halo effect of external raters who can base their assessments on overall impressions as well as observe behaviors designed to impress supervisors. In addition, self-report measures are a valid approach to measuring proactivity (Parker et al., 2006). Furthermore, some of our context variables are objective measures (i.e., complexity) and thus should limit the potential for common method bias. To further minimize the potential for common method bias, we intermixed items of different constructs on the questionnaire, used different response formats for the dependent and independent variables, and protected respondent anonymity.

Another limitation of our study is that all variables were measured at one point in time, and thus we cannot infer causality. Future research should adopt a longitudinal perspective, thus making possible the inference of causality, and allowing for a reflection of the dynamic nature of adaptive and proactive behaviors and how they contribute to organizational change success. Our study also leaves unanswered an important question about the performance implications of adaptive and proactive behaviors. We have argued that adaptive and proactive behaviors should be positive in the context of new curriculum implementation in public schools. This would seem to be a reasonable assumption but further research is needed to empirically link adaptive and proactive teacher behavior to indicators of school and student performance after the adoption of the new curriculum.

A final limitation of our study is the generalizability of our findings. We collected data across a large number of organizations, which should enhance generalizability. On the other hand, we deliberately developed measures of adaptive and proactive behaviors that are largely context-specific for reasons that we have highlighted in our methods. Of course, this strategy limits the direct applicability of our measures to other change contexts. An advantage of context-specific measures is that general statements for adaptive behavior (i.e., “I adapt well to change”) and proactive behavior (i.e., “I make things happen”) might result in less valid answers because of social desirability, relative to context-specific measures where social desirability is less obvious (Bindl & Parker, 2010; Parker et al., 2006). Furthermore, generalized measures of proactive behavior tend to capture more of a stable disposition to be proactive (such as proactive personality) than proactive behavior. The problem with measuring a stable disposition as a measure for a situation-specific behavior is that differences across situations might not be captured (Bindl & Parker, 2010). Of course, besides the low generalizability to other samples, context-specific measures also require more resources than generalized measures because they need to be specifically developed for the research. However, we believe that our approach to operationalizing adaptive and proactive behaviors is applicable to other contexts and thus could be used as a guide for designing measures of these behaviors in other contexts.

In terms of strengths, we gathered data across a large number of individuals and organizations. We also used a mixed-method research strategy by combining observations of work practice, interviews, archival data, and surveys. Therefore, we were able to combine the richness of qualitative work with the rigor of quantitative analysis. Furthermore, we adopted a process perspective on jobs to examine two types of behavior with relevance to managing change in contemporary organizations. Our process perspective recognizes the importance of understanding how work is carried out during change and unpacks its adaptive and proactive components as well as the contextual influences on these behaviors. Research on adaptive and proactive behaviors is a relatively recent undertaking in organizational studies in general, and in change research in particular. Our research highlights the importance of understanding the adaptive and proactive behaviors that employees engage in to make change happen in contemporary organizational settings and provides important insights for managing organizational change.

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: Brenda E. Ghitulescu is an assistant professor of management in the School of Business at the College of New Jersey. She received her PhD in organizational behavior from the University of Pittsburgh. Her research interests include the impact of work design on employee proactivity and job crafting, the processes underlying individual creativity, and organizational change.
